dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight breeze gently sways the green and purple crop. The CHIRP of CICADA is the only sound.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: But suddenly the CHIRPING GETS LOUDER and LOUDER -- BZZZZZ! -- until we realize it's not the cicadas, but a -- SWOOOSH! A lethal, razor-sharp DISC BUZZES up over the horizon, swoops TOWARD the CAMERA and OUT OF FRAME! The CAMERA SPINS AROUND to see the disc flying away, chasing a man, THADDEUS MORTON, wearing a strange metallic collar -- exhausted, horrified, about to die.

dialogues.speaker: MORTON
dialogues.text: He looks over his shoulder, panting -- he's been running forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madman... Hideous spider... Run... Run! Warn the President... Morton zig-zags through a grove of trees, a desperate attempt to avoid the horrible serrated disc. But the ruse is futile. The disc goes straight through the trees, slicing a path straight as the crow flies.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WAGON
dialogues.text: dilapidated, broken down, weathering away in the field. Morton runs around the wagon -- but the DISC BUZZES straight through the sideboards! Wood shavings spit everywhere! There's no stopping this thing.

dialogues.speaker: MORTON
dialogues.text: running for his life -- stops, turns. He turns, incomprehensibly mumbling, pleading for his life, cowering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooooo!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: A1 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And the DISC SWOOSHES TOWARD the CAMERA -- BZZZZZZZ!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SKY FULL OF STARS
dialogues.text: A man leans INTO FRAME. This is GENERAL McGRATH.      And he's there to collect the silver death disc. McGRATH (to the unseen, dead Morton) And they says you scientists are supposed to be smart.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: HOOVES THUNDER by. Then bouncing, skidding wagon wheels. Up on the empty buckboard is a pair of murderous ex-Rebs. As the Rebs pass a pint of whisky, lash the six-horse team on, PAN WITH the wagon to see it's headed for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALOON GIRL (O.S.) The legendary Captain James West and I finally got him all to myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEST is bathing with the beatiful SALOON GIRL. WEST That's right, sugar, and you should feel free to treat him just bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves in and kisses him, long and hard. West hears the CLATTER of the APPROACHING WAGONS. He stops the kiss and peeks out the knothole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below, West sees the wagon with the Rebs. WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                            3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEST (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General McGrath's boys. I thought y'all was never gonna show up. SALOON GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister West, you wouldn't be here workin' tonight, now would you? WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. 'Course not. Not tonight. Would you be working if you were up here with you? SALOON GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. They start kissing again. He surreptitiously peeks out the knothole, while continuing his kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This two-story, Victorian building across town is a "gentlemen's sporting house" in name only. Drunken roughnecks and ex-Confederate soldiers goose and maul the rouged-up tarts.

dialogues.speaker: AT BAR
dialogues.text: shrinks back from the moronic ribaldry. The Toulouse Lautrec lighting only accentuates her garish hair and makeup, identifying her as a SOILED DOVE. A whore -- not to put too fine a point on it. She's trying not to make eye contact with two men seated at a table across the parlor. SOILED DOVE'S POV - GEN. McGRATH AND HUDSON HUDSON is a fearsome-looking Indian in a well-tailored suit. Long black braids descend incongruously from under a homburg hat. As for his companion... McGRATH is a mountain of drunken pus. Six foot, sweating like a Devonshire hog with his tattered, undersized Confederate dress jacket buttoned all the way to the top. His ear has been hacked off and replaced by what looks to be a miniature leather Victrola horn. McGrath smiles at our Soiled Dove and makes a little kissing gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                            4

dialogues.speaker: SOILED DOVE
dialogues.text: Eyes widened in revulsion. What evil abides in this Godforsaken place? Now a drunkenly EYE-CROSSED REB licks Dora's ear, then whispers something in it. Something unspeakably vile, by Dora's expression. DORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That won't be possible. I have... tonsillitis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rebs load the boxes onto the wagon. We see the wheel of the wagon up against the rotted leg of the water tower. BIG REB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack'er up good, Virgil.    Next stop N'Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West is unaware that she's watching him, not watching her. SALOON GIRL (admonishing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim! WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, this hole is a safety issue. I'm thinking, what if it starts to rain and the water level goes up. It could suck you right up. I'm protecting you. (variations) Saloon Girl frustrated, has grabbed West's boxer shorts (with little horses on them) and plugs the hole with them. SALOON GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem solved. WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belle, you don't just ram a man's underbritches into a knothole. You wanna plug the hole, you ram your own britches in there. West is at a loss.    She moves in for another kiss. WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HORSES SPOOK as a crate is dropped onto the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: AXLE
dialogues.text: caught on the WATER TOWER LEG.    It CREAKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West hears the CREAK.    He breaks the kiss. SALOON GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jim. WEST (serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much as I'd like to take credit for that you might need to hand me my gun... The tower starts to topple. WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hand me my gun. It CRASHES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West crashes down into the tarp covering the boxes. The only people more shocked than he is are the guards and the Rebs he just dropped in on. West picks himself up, smiles coolly at the drenched slack-jaws. WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, who just made a wish? Was it you? He looks up at the freaked-out Saloon Girl, still in the tank. She hangs on with one hand, the other hand clutches his clothes. WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could sure use those clothes now. She responds by Frisbee-ing his hat down. West picks it up, with a look... uses it to cover his genitals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                           4B

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BIG REB Well, we got us a shy nig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he never gets that word out. Bang! West lashes a lightning martial arts kick to the Reb's jaw. WEST Fought five long years with the Union Army not to hear that word again. And you boys lost, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the other Reb comes at him, he spins, still holding the hat in front of him... and whap! Down that one goes. West looks up at the none-too-bright water tank woman. WEST How 'bout some pants!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she throws the rest of his clothes down in a heap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General McGrath checks a pocket watch, looks up impatiently at the Indian, Hudson. His eyes drift upwards... to the balcony where...

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS BALCONY
dialogues.text: have come up back stairs lugging a heavy steamer trunk. McGRATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still waiting on my guns and ammo, but I see my men have brought your merchandise. McGrath subtly gestures with his eyes to the balcony for Hudson to confirm. Hudson nods. McGRATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had expected to be delivering it personally to Mr... Hudson quickly cuts him off before he can say the name. The Indian speaks in a very precise King's English. HUDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My employer, here in a brothel? (a small ironic smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be quite... redundant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE IN ON an elegant brougham driven by a very large, very striking woman in livery. As the carriage passes under the gas lamp, we can make out the top-hatted silhouette of McGrath's "employer," DR. ARLISS LOVELESS. Clustered around him inside the cab are three more beautiful women. As he strokes the cheek of the ORIENTAL one with the back of his hand like a cat... 14   INT. FAT-CAN'S - McGRATH AND HUDSON - NIGHT HUDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll meet him when the time -- and place -- are appropriate. Now... (stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... shall we go upstairs to check the 'merchandise'?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McGRATH Frankly, Mr. Hudson, I wasn't planning to walk those oaken stairs with you. Direct me to the poot, sir. Something young and creamy. A gamer that takes to the crop and spur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath looks to the singer (Rita), who beats a hasty retreat from him after her song. So, once again, McGrath lays his rheumy eyes on...

dialogues.speaker: SOILED DOVE
dialogues.text: She's oblivious, more intrigued by the ex-Rebs on the balcony with the trunk. As she starts for the stairs... a man's hand grabs her. It's the Eye-Crossed Reb again. EYE-CROSSED REB You drive a hard bargain, lady. All right, fifty cents to take them big juicy lips and... DORA Still not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to pull away.    But the Reb won't let go. EYE-CROSSED REB But you gotta be interested. You're a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the coquettishness in the eyes becomes rage. The falsetto becomes a baritone growl. DORA (baritone) That doesn't mean a girl can't have high standards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as the Reb registers the odd new voice... wham!    H corsage springs out and whacks him right in the jaw.    T Reb's eyes roll back... and he slumps to the ground. Whooa, hoss... the Soiled Dove is a man! He's ARTEMUS GORDON and his true profession will be revealed to us shortly. But now, as he/she stashes the unconscious Reb behind the bar, straightens bosom and wig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West is trying to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he pulls on one leg of his pants, a guard lunges at him with a knife. West hops up on one leg, smacks the guy with a mule kick. Now he puts his arm through his shirt sleeve. When the hand emerges out of the cuff, it's balled in a fist -- which coldcocks the other guard. WEST Could I have a little privacy here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if in response, the water tower, still hovering above, now crashes to the floor -- obliterating his opponents. WEST Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calmly looks up in time to catch the falling, naked, screaming Saloon Girl in his arms. WEST You'll have to excuse me, darlin'... but my evidence is getting away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West gallantly puts her down, jumps up, grabs the overhead block and tackle system and slides through the warehouse. As the HORSE TEAM, which has spooked, THUNDERS past...

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: sails onto the runaway wagon. As he pulls himself into the back, he gives the shivering Saloon Girl a tip of his hat -- now on his head. WEST Sorry about there not being any towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General McGrath   leers down a line-up of Fat-Can's girls Just as he gets   to the beautiful singer, who looks sick at the thought,   suddenly Gordon intrudes. He/she blocks out the singer,   poses coquettishly -- sucking a lollypop. McGRATH What's your name, missy?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON/DORA (demurely; back to his falsetto) Dora. Would you like to go upstairs? McGRATH Oh, indeedy I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon/Dora starts to go as the Eye-Crossed Reb wakes up. He grabs him/her, very pissed. EYE-CROSSED REB Hey, c'mere!   Who the hell are you anyway?! McGRATH She's... mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blam! McGrath emphasizes his claim by gut-shooting the Reb. The shot makes Dora/Gordon jump and the room go quiet. As the Reb crumples, McGrath turns back to Gordon/Dora, oddly inspired. McGRATH I feel like... a ditty! GORDON/DORA A ditty? But General... (trying to be coquettish again) ... my talents really lay elsewhere. McGRATH Nothing stokes the fire in my loins like a ditty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath hauls him/her over to the piano player. McGRATH You've got some pretty fair lungs on ya, girl, now use 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punctuates with a slap to Gordon/Dora's rump.      The other singer (Rita) watches too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon/Dora is sweating. Reluctantly, he/she whispers something to the piano player. He clears his throat and begins singing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON/DORA (weakly) 'Buy a drink for the boys In the backroom for me...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West spots the contents of an open box.    Eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: stuck in sand. But clinking together ominously as the wagon races over the cobblestones. WEST Backwards-ass bumpkins got a wagon full of nitro...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West tries to steady the glass vials with his hands... but it's no use. He quickly climbs over the boxes, onto the buckboard seat. But the reins are dragging on the ground beneath the frothing horses. West leaps onto the horses as the wagon careens down the street. He pulls himself over the first one's neck... onto the next horse. And as he tries for the lead horse, he falls between them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon/Dora singing. He/she struggles through the song in a very tough room. GORDON/DORA 'And tell them I tried... And tell them I cried...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just when it looks like the stone-faced rowdies might rip him/her apart, McGrath starts tapping a mud-caked toe. Encouraged, Gordon/Dora belts out the next verses OVER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West's custom boots drag in the dirt as he's about to be trampled under the hooves of the freaked-out horses. And if he hasn't got enough problems, the lynch pin attaching the team to the wagon has almost worked its way out.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLANKING together like chimes...

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: Straining with every ounce of strength in his body, he pulls himself up by the harness onto...

dialogues.speaker: WILD-EYED LEAD HORSE
dialogues.text: West grabs for the halter. WEST Whoa now...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't whoa. The wagon goes around a corner up on two wheels! It's about to tilt over when West grabs both the horses' ears, yanks them back -- screaming into them. WEST I said, whoa!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This approach seems to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team comes to an abrupt stop... and with it the wagon hanging over the edge of a steep drop. Jim carefully climbs off. He slaps the dust on his jacket, straightens the crease in his trousers. When he looks up, a bitter smile. WEST Well, well, this is workin' out to be a perfect day. My man...

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIAN BUILDING
dialogues.text: The tasteful sign under the red light reads: "FAT-CAN CANDY'S." And framed in the window, General McGrath with his singing soiled dove. WEST (O.S.) ... General Bloodbath McGrath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22   INT. FAT-CAN'S - CLOSE - McGRATH McGrath is clapping with the crowd of misfits who are now singing along with Gordon/Dora. He/she's won over the roo GORDON/CROWD (rousing finish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tell them I tried just the same...! He/she curtsies to rousing applause. McGrath beams like a man with the fire in his loins roaring. He grabs his little songbird and up the stairs they go. Out the WINDOWS, we see West tracking them.    Simul- taneously going up outside steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leads the sweating, leering General down the hall. He/she quickly opens and closes boudoir doors -- ostensibly to find a free room for their assignation. The real agenda is to find the mysterious trunk.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Quick peek. He/she registers a mild reaction of shock. Closes that door and moves on to...

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Quick peek. The two rebs sitting on the trunk. At their feet is a wriggling burlap sack. The "merchandise" is ali Gordon/Dora giggles like a schoolgirl. GORDON/DORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a new one. McGrath slams the door, drags Gordon/Dora roughly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our soiled dove has her back to the door as if steeling herself for the task at hand. McGrath beckons her over to the bed. McGRATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the ear scare you.    I lost it at Chickamauga. Gordon/Dora squints at the jerry-rigged ear.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON/DORA Oh really. One can hardly notice... (fiddles with her belt buckle) Would you mind...? I... I... can't seem to release the clasp of my belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say no more. McGrath is on her like a flash, fidgeting with it. But it pops open, revealing a spiraling screen courtesy of Dr. Mesmer. His eyes lock onto it. McGRATH Wha... what's this? GORDON/DORA It's a deep, deep pool. Maybe your old swimmin' hole. Getting sleepy, General? McGRATH (ga-ga) Yes, I'm sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath sits on the floor.        Gordon smiles... this i gonna be easy. GORDON (normal voice) Good. You're going to be my little doggy. And when I say 'speak,' you tell me everything I want to know. Understood? McGRATH (barks) Woof! GORDON All right, little doggy. Sit up. (as he does) Now tell me who's in the sack next door. Is it the scientist, Dr. Escobar? Speak! McGRATH Woof!   Woof! GORDON Speak words, dumb doggy! Tell me the name of the man you kidnapped him for...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But McGrath doesn't answer. Gordon's Mesmer spiral slows to a stop. McGrath is coming out of the trance. McGrath starts to growl, rip at his/her petticoats. GORDON Watch the swirling spiral!   Lie down, bad dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gordon notices that his contraption's failed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is busy trying to get the spiral going again, doesn't see McGrath reach for his boot knife. Just as the deranged general's about to plunge it into Gordon/Dora... ... the WINDOW EXPLODES. Jim West comes tumbling into the room, kicks the knife out of McGrath's hand in one smooth move. West rolls to his feet, fixes a gallant smile on Gordon/Dora. WEST Didn't mean to startle you, ma'am. Looked like you could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Gordon a moment to recover. He stares at this black Samaritan, obviously having no clue who he is. GORDON (clears throat to recover falsetto) Looks can be deceivin'... dark stranger. I am perfectly fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West quickly pats McGrath down, removes a revolver and his bag of gold coins. WEST I can see that, darlin'. Woman of your caliber probably gets top dollar, too. So here you go. (flips her McGrath's coin bag) You can run along. I'll take care of McGrath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As West sticks the barrel of his gun in McGrath's gramophone ear, Gordon's eyes pop.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON/DORA No!   I need him! WEST C'mon, lady. You got the money. Have a little dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon jerks West's gun hand away from McGrath's head just as the dog-soldier comes around. McGrath suddenly lunges at him. McGRATH (bellows ferociously) West...!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives his full weight into Jim's back, pushing him ou into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath's rebel yell brings help from all directions. DOORS BANG open all along the hallway. Not just McGrath's men, but Hudson and his crew. A melee will ensue. West pushes the monster off of him, rolls as a BULLET SPLINTERS the WOOD where he just was. The SHOT STARTS...

dialogues.speaker: STAMPEDE OF SEMI-CLAD WHORES
dialogues.text: all screaming hysterically and heading for the exits. The beautiful young singer, who'd been coming up the stairs alone, is now swept back down them. Gordon, still in character, pushes his way upstream to th room where the scientist is held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudson, his back turned, barking orders at his henchmen. HUDSON Get Escobar out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The henchmen heft the wriggling sack, when: GORDON (O.S.) Leave him right there.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hudson whirls to see the gruff-talking Gordon/Dora holdin the perfume bottle on him like it's a Colt 45. Now Gordon shakes one of the heavy bracelets off his wrist, CLICKS a LOCK, snapping it open. He's accessorized with custom handcuffs. GORDON Let's go, Hudson... hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudson gives a sick little smile, reaches for his gun when... WSSSSHT! Gordon sprays him in the eyes with the second bulb of the atomizer. (The first Mace!) Hudson howls in pain, drops the gun, rubs his eyes madly with both hands. GORDON Thank... you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon starts to snap the cuffs on the perfectly presented wrists when...

dialogues.speaker: FAT-CAN'S
dialogues.text: brawling a dozen attackers. West spots McGrath trying to escape down the stairs. He uncorks a lethal kick, sending a thug flying through the doorway and into the back of Gordon. Gordon staggers, drops the perfume/mace BOTTLE which SHATTERS. Hudson recovers his vision enough to send a fist into Gordon's mascaraed face, pile-driving him back into the hall. While Hudson and his men make their escape down the back stairs with the scientist sack...

dialogues.speaker: WEST AND GORDON
dialogues.text: West is blocked from chasing McGrath, Gordon from going after Hudson. West tries to push her aside. WEST U.S. Army... Now get outta my way, lady! GORDON (the baritone growl) I'm no lady! I'm a U.S. Marshal! You get out of my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon whip off his wig, reaches inside it for something. West blinks at the weirdness, reflexively draws his Colt. As Gordon withdraws not a gun, but a badge, from his wig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is waiting at the top of the hill beside the nitro wagon. Dr. Loveless is beside it, face still shadowed.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CARRIAGE
dialogues.text: has opera glasses trained on the second story of Fat- Can's. Her name is LIPPENREIDER. And now we'll see why. LIPPENREIDER (in a monotone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my way... get out of my way... U.S. Army... U.S. Marshal. LOVELESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear... The lip-reading is interrupted by the arrival of...

dialogues.speaker: TOP OF INCLINE
dialogues.text: who come racing up with the scientist-in-the-sack. HUDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Federal agents inside, sir! LOVELESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Miss Lippenreider informs me. (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, I believe good manners dictate we should send out... His cane telescopes out and Loveless pokes the lynch pin out of the harness on the nitro wagon. Then he gives the wagon the slightest push. LOVELESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the welcome wagon. Once started, the wagon rolls downhill, toward the back door of Fat-Can Candy's, picking up speed... Then, as his female coterie pulls the burlap sack into the carriage, Loveless steps in behind. And they're off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West and Gordon, oblivious to the impending disaster... WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now what...?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The answer is provided as the NITRO WAGON hits downstairs. KABOOOOOOM!!!    THEME MUSIC UP... as we roll...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLES
dialogues.text: The titles are the familiar animated freeze frames from the TV show. In the two corners are our heroes -- Upper left shows West with his gun levelled toward... upper right -- Gordon with his wig in one hand and his badge in the other, pointed across toward West. The cowboy/agent in the middle square fights and defeats the various bad guys. Then as he exits, QUICK ZOOM ON main title: "THE WILD WILD WEST." PAN DOWN TO a sketch of a train caboose as TITLES END...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West rides his magnificent black stallion down Pennsylvania Avenue. Besides horse-drawn carriages, West shares the dusty road with people on bicycles -- the latest craze. He finally pulls his steed up at his destination...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West dismounts, ties his horse to a hitching post and winces as he puts his weight on a sore leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West limps past black floor scrubbers. They stop working to marvel at this handsome black man dressed in custom cowboy duds walking in there like he owns the place. But not everybody's so impressed. As West heads toward the Oval Office, four self-important house detectives block his way. HOUSE DETECTIVE Whoa there, 'pardner.' (as West stops) Winning the war may have got you forty acres and a mule, but you can't just traipse into the President's office. Now gimme that gun.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He nods at the six gun on West's hip. West coolly flexes his hand above it, like he's about to draw... WEST This gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then like lightning, with his other hand, he whips out a sawed-off shotgun hidden by his jacket. He pokes the 12-gauge barrels up against Pinkerton's surprised crotch. WEST Or this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice stops the situation from escalating further. PRESIDENT GRANT (O.S.) Gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detective's head swivels around to see...

dialogues.speaker: OVAL OFFICE DOOR
dialogues.text: stands in the doorway. PRESIDENT GRANT Don't make Captain West any later for his appointment than he already is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives back away from the hair-trigger cowboy as fast as they can. West reholsters the gun and continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Grant goes over to his desk, lights a cigar. Backlit in the haze, the portly bearded figure lives up to the myth. PRESIDENT GRANT Been a lot of death threats lately ... Cabinet made me hire some damn detectives. (by way of apology) Drink, cigar? WEST Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West limps across the room to the bar, pours himself a glass of whiskey, takes a cigar out of the humidor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT GRANT I hear you let General McGrath get away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now West's blood is up. WEST Sir, I had him right in my hands when some half-a-sissy wearin' a dress ruined... PRESIDENT GRANT (cuts him off) Artemus Gordon. WEST You... know him? PRESIDENT GRANT Of course I know him, he's the best marshal I've got! He's a genius. (off West's incredulous look) Gordon has proven himself time and again as a very cunning operator with a rapacious intellect. Nothing will stop him from completing a mission for his President... except the impulsive actions of a headstrong cowboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West just looks at him soberly. Draws his gun and places it against the President's head. Grant's eyes widen. WEST Who are you? PRESIDENT GRANT I am the President of the United States!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West points the GUN to the ceiling and pulls the trigger. BLAM!!! As Grant jumps a foot and plaster rains down... WEST Wrong answer.    Who are you? PRESIDENT GRANT I am the President of... (as West cocks gun) ... I'm Artemus Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: West lowers his gun, nods at Gordon's class ring. WEST The President went to West Point ... not Harvard. PRESIDENT GRANT (O.S.) Will somebody tell me what the hell this stunt is all about!?!

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT GRANT
dialogues.text: (the real one) stands in the doorway, hands on hips, surrounded by his house detectives -- their guns drawn. West nudges the fake Grant in the fake belly with his gun barrel -- go ahead. Sheepishly, Gordon starts peeling off his primitive, but effective, facial prosthetics. GORDON Sir, in perilous times like these, I was simply illustrating how someone impersonating you could actually walk right into the very bowels of the White House...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Gordon makes his intestinal allusion, West takes a ceremonial bayonet off Grant's desk and pokes a hole in the inflated bladder that was his fake paunch. The AIR HISSES out, finishes deflating with a flatulent R-R-RIP. (Hey, the first whoopee cushion?) Gordon scowls at him. PRESIDENT GRANT You're clever, Gordon. One day it'll get you killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West smirks as Grant looks up at the bullet hole in the ceiling, then fixes West with a disapproving eye. PRESIDENT GRANT ... And you, West -- not every situation calls for your patented approach of shoot first, shoot later, shoot again -- then when they're all dead, try to ask a question or two. (shakes his head) Working together will be good for both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 6/15/98

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST AND GORDON But, sir, I work... PRESIDENT GRANT You work the way your Commander In Chief tells you to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant turns and EXITS FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a buzzing intelligence operations center -- state-of-the-art for the 1860's. Maps of the U.S. and the world are on the wall. Various staff and military people work CLACKING TELEGRAPHS, PRINTING MACHINES that GRIND out reports, etc. Grant stops at a display of daguerreotype photos, all depicting distinguished bewhiskered men. PRESIDENT GRANT Ten of our country's best scientists... all kidnapped in the last year. By General McGrath, it now seems. (turns to them) The fact is, gentlemen, you've both been working on the same case all along. Why did it take you so long to realize it? WEST Well, sir, one of us was still trying to figure out if he was a man or a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives snicker over that one.    Grant's had enough. PRESIDENT GRANT I don't have time for this bickering! One week, if we're to believe this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant holds out a letter to Gordon and West.      Gordon snatches it, reads: PRESIDENT GRANT (reading) 'General Grant, the scientists that you seek are in my employ -- (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 6/15/98                       2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT GRANT (CONT'D) -- Creating a weapons system beyond the pale of contemporary imagination. History and justice are on my side. I suggest you put your affairs in order. You have one week before you will surrender the U.S. Government.'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT GRANT This letter was delivered inside this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aide presents a glass case.     Inside is a cake in th shape of the White House. GORDON (reaching inside) Marzipan, isn't it? PRESIDENT GRANT (grabs his hand) Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly dozens of deadly-looking spiders swarm out from inside the cake. Gordon jerks his hand back. WEST It's McGrath, sir. The South is rising again. I'm gonna stop it. GORDON Sir, West's obsession aside, McGrath may be a vicious killer, but a mastermind he is not. So whom do we seek? After consulting with Intelligence... WEST (cuts him off) McGrath's headed for New Orleans. The longer we stand here talkin', the farther away he gets. I don't need 'Intelligence' to tell me that. GORDON Ah, so that would mean you rely on ... Stupidity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant's had enough. PRESIDENT GRANT Gentlemen! I'm leaving today for Utah where the transcontinental railroads will be joined at Promontory Point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant points to a map of the United States. The railroad lines have been drawn in... still a gap between them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT GRANT For the first time the United States will truly be united. (turns, holds up letter) Someone wants us divided. Now look, you two are the best I've got. Put aside your differences and stop this madman... whoever he is. If you fail, well... we may never know how great this country could've been. (snaps off a salute) You have a week. Dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both return Grant's salute as the President stomps off. His AIDE now approaches. AIDE The President has put a private train at your disposal. Engine number five, track six. (holds out a wrapped box) Mr. Gordon, the item you requested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon takes the box, hurries to catch up with West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West and Gordon, walking toward the hitching post. West is so beside himself he can barely untie his high-voltage stud. He glowers at Gordon who goes over to where...

dialogues.speaker: STRANGE-LOOKING BICYCLE
dialogues.text: Is parked on the other side of a bush. It has the customary big wheel in the front, little wheel in the back. (Hidden from sight is a motor on the front tire. Dual manifolds that sling under the rider's legs.) West shakes his head in disgust. WEST Figures. GORDON I call it the Bi-axle Nitro- Combust...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Save it.   I've gotta train to catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West swings into the saddle. He looks at the SNORTING wild HORSE under him, then down at Gordon attaching the box onto the seat of his Nitro-whatever. WEST (snaps off a smug salute) Yee-haaa!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West spurs his horse and leaves Gordon in the proverbial cloud of dust. Although West's intentions are clear, for some reason, Gordon's in no particular hurry. He sighs, climbs on the bike, takes out a hankie and cleans a pair of goggles. Then, finally ready... GORDON Avant!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VROOOM! An ENGINE KICKS IN and Gordon rockets forward. (Yep, Artemus has invented the first motorcycle!) Fiery exhaust blasts out of the manifolds as the bike propels him down the street at about 60 mph right past...

dialogues.speaker: WEST AND HIS STALLION
dialogues.text: who both look over in wide-eyed shock. The horse rears as Gordon SCREAMS by -- leaving them in a cloud of internal combustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From in front, as it CHUGS TOWARDS us. Sitting up in the spanking new steam engine (No. 5) is a white-haired Coleman. The Wanderer is his pride and joy. Coleman pushes the throttle forward and the ENGINE ROARS PAST us... followed by a tender, and two gleaming passenger cars. Then comes West THUNDERING past in a desperate effort to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: WITH WEST
dialogues.text: riding like hell. Getting the last ounce of speed out of his well-lathered steed, he finally pulls alongside the rear passenger car. He looks up... In the window, we see Gordon engrossed in what he's doing... which appears to be sewing. WEST Stop this train!! You hear me!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Gordon hears him, he pretends not to.    He just casually makes the next stitch. West's horse has had it. They're losing ground to the train. At the last second, West leans over at full gallop and grabs a handle on the side of the train. He swings out of the saddle, hanging on for dear life, blowing in the breeze like laundry. Finally, his boot finds a small metal plate to put its weight on. Just as West stands safely on it... whoosh! He flies up in the air and drops through a sliding partition in the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is like a classy Victorian men's club. Bar stocked with crystal decanters, a pool table, decorative pistols on the wall, books, etc. Gordon, seated in a club chair, looks over as West falls from the ceiling into a seat. He's hot, dusty and very pissed off. He glowers at Gordon murderously. GORDON (calmly) Thanks for dropping in. WEST Forget the bikes, the beards, the fake boobies. Put down the needlepoint and let's settle this like men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off jacket, starts rolling up his sleeves. Gordon remains remarkably cool, continues sewing. GORDON As a matter of clarification, this isn't needlepoint. This is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows him some real needlepoint.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON Right now, I'm putting the final touches on a new invention of my creation. I call it... The Impermeable. It's a vest that, when worn under the clothing, can stop any modern bullet fired even at close range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West draws his gun, aims it at Gordon's stomach and cocks the trigger. WEST Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon quickly pulls the vest away from his stomach. GORDON But it hasn't been really tested empirically yet. WEST Get up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West takes off his guns and puts them on the table. GORDON (yawn, yawn) Guns. I find them so primitive and unnecessary... if one has done one's proper planning. WEST Yeah?   How do you feel about a fist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon puts down The Impermeable, stands with a weary sigh. GORDON I must tell you, Mr. West, I've always felt that allowing a situation to degenerate into physical violence is a failure on my part. WEST Well then, 'Mr.' Gordon, you failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whap! West unleashes a lightning punch that drives Gordon across the train car. He dabs at his bloody lip.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON I'm sorry, Mr. West, you brought this on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then to West's utter amazement, Gordon puts his hands together as if praying while at the same time, crooking his right leg stork-like. Is this some kind of martial art? Then, he bends at the waist, and like a ballet dancer, extends his leg out to the wall and flips a switch. It immediately triggers a leather hammer to swing down from the ceiling. It whacks West on the side of the head, and sends him spinning back onto the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: POOL TABLE
dialogues.text: shakes it off and is about to attack again. Gordon calmly pokes a hidden button. Suddenly the pool table revolves. West is gone. GORDON I love this train!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West, eyes wide, is clinging on for dear life, staring at the ties racing by, inches from his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon pours a fine Bordeaux, speaks loudly toward floor. GORDON The President asked for my suggestions on how to make the Wanderer both comfortable and functional...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he swishes the wine in his mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West reaches up to get a handhold in the myriad of tubes and wires on the underside of the car. As he rips one tube out of the undercarriage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon has just settled into the club chair, puts his win down on the table. GORDON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while you're down there, you may want to avail yourself of my Sub-carriage Inter-rail Egressor... Suddenly SHACKLES SNAP out of the arms of the chair, pinning Gordon's wrists. Before he knows what hit him, the floor opens and the club chair disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon appears upside down in the chair, chagrined at his predicament. West looks from the escape trolley Gordon was talking about back to his partner. WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one doin' any 'egressin' is gonna be you. GORDON (wide-eyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the President was right about us putting aside our petty differences. (recites above the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The opposite is beneficial, from things that differ comes the fairest attunement.' Aristotle. Suddenly they flip OUT OF FRAME and back into the car, shocked to find themselves facing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman's a scowling, grizzled old man in a coal-stained suit. He's got a fire in his eye, brown spittle in the corner of his mouth where a cigarette butt lives permanently, and a large copper pot in his hand. COLEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock each other about all ya please, but harm my train and I'll douse ya like dogs. He threatens them with the pot of steaming liquid.   Now, for the first time, Gordon really looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON That's my veal reduction sauce! COLEMAN Well then, let's get on about our business, shall we, gentlemen? Now, where to? WEST New Orleans. GORDON Shall we let Professor Morton decide? WEST Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A severed human head is in a vise. GORDON Meet Professor Thaddeus Morton, expert in the field of metallurgy ... discovered in a field of alfalfa. Kidnapped from M.I.T. six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West looks from the head to the open box. WEST That's a man's head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon holds up a strange, circular metallic object. GORDON ... And this magnetic collar was around it when his body was discovered. Haven't figured that one out yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But West is still staring in disbelief at the head. WEST That's a man's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon starts fiddling with a lantern positioned behind the head.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON According to the Retinal Terminus Theory... a dying person's last conscious image is burned into the back of the eyeball like a photograph.   Perhaps there's a clue there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited, Gordon turns on the lantern attached to the back of his head. Beams of light are coming through his eyeballs, creating a blurry color image on the wall. GORDON Morton's last image! WEST That's a man's head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West turns his head sideways to try to view the inverted image projected on the wall. Gordon realizes the problem. GORDON Ah. The refraction of the lenses causes the image to appear upside down. We simply...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns Morton's head in the vise.      It's right side but still blurry.

dialogues.speaker: WALL
dialogues.text: appears. It's a man who has a tiny Victrola horn for an ear. He's holding a bloody metal boomerang. WEST It's McGrath.    I was right all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon sees something in McGrath's pocket. GORDON He seems to have something in his pocket... too fuzzy to read, though...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon drums his fingers on his great frontal lobe, stymied. GORDON Mortification of the aqueous humor seems to have led to the loss of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                           31

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST ... glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West takes the bifocals out of the box, casually puts the on Morton's nose. West now gestures to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGE ON WALL
dialogues.text: The white blur in the man's pocket is now focused. We can see that it's the top of a piece of paper. He reads the writing on it. WEST 'Friends of the South! Come to a Surprise Costume Ball. April 14, eight-thirty. 346 Garden Street... ' (lowers glasses, looks up) Like I said.... New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Wanderer parked on the siding as we hear voice over. GORDON (V.O.) How about this? You could come as my man servant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon has his wardrobe open. Selected from his vast array of costumes and disguises is a full livery outfit. GORDON How about this? You could come as my man servant. WEST (slave voice) Oh yes, Massa Gordon, dats what I'll do. And I'll jus' smile and do as I's tole so those people won' ever know that I would rather shoot myself in the head than play your god damned man servant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West is right in Gordon's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON I have a horse costume. (then, cheery) You could be the head. WEST The only thing I need to wear is this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West straps on his holster. GORDON Okay, if you insist on carrying a firearm, I have something I think you'll find intriguing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon displays a belt with a silver buckle. He taps the buckle... a Derringer pops out. West stares, impressed. GORDON And it would go nicely with this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon takes out a sequined dress, holds the Derringer up against it. WEST Jim West does not wear a dress. GORDON Then what's your plan? WEST How 'bout this: I'll go as a government agent who's gonna kill McGrath. GORDON An armed, Negro cowboy costume, how creative. In a room full of white Southerners, you oughtta fit right in. You might even win first prize!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West starts to walk away.    Gordon grabs him. GORDON Listen to me. The art of disguise is what's going to get us into that party, thus allowing us to find these kidnapped scientists before they're forced to create something that will destroy this great country. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON (CONT'D) Now you and I are the chosen ones, Jim. We're under direct orders from the President himself. And our mission is clear: Save our country. Our freedom is at stake and this is our duty as men. Now, you go as a riverboat captain and I'll be a saloon girl. WEST Let me tell you a little something about beloved 'art of disguise'... That night at Fat-Can's, I knew you weren't a woman. GORDON But I was propositioned by three men. WEST Gordon, you looked nasty. Your breasts were all hard and stiff, and were sticking straight out like two rusty cannons on a sunken ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon grabs his fake breasts off the rack.       He puts them on. GORDON These are a work of art. Scientifically and aesthetically perfect. WEST They look like shit. GORDON Touch them. WEST I don't wanna touch 'em.   I can see I don't like 'em. GORDON What, are you afraid you're wrong? Touch my breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West touches Gordon's fake breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: walking through the next car, carrying a tray of tea. Gordon's last line got his attention. What the...? Coleman peeks around the corner to see West eyeing Gordon's "chest." COLEMAN (to himself) I knew it. Well, I'll have no part of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman shakes his head and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: WEST AND GORDON
dialogues.text: West is thwapping Gordon's breasts. WEST There, Gordon, you happy? I'm touching your breasts. GORDON Not so rough.    The buckwheat'll come out. WEST Buckwheat?   That's your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West takes one of the cow udders out of Gordon's bodice and dumps the buckwheat onto the ground. GORDON What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West goes over to a wash basin, picks up a water pitcher and fills the cow bladder. West squeezes the cow bladder shut and holds it up to his chest. WEST Now, squeeze this. This is what a breast should feel like.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Passing back through the next car. When he hears that last line, he can't believe it. He peeks in again to see... GORDON Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Isn't that nice? GORDON Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman's mouth drops.     He's sweating. WEST Now touch yourself. GORDON You win.   I'm hard. COLEMAN (disgusted) Federal officers, bah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman walks off, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Gordon shoots the cuffs off his jacket. Out of one sleeve comes a pen. Out the other, a small pad of paper. They are both connected to a spring-loaded metal gizmo up his sleeve. West reacts, drawing his pistol up into Gordon's face. GORDON I was just going to jot down a thought. WEST You know something, that's a good place to put a gun. GORDON But then, where would I keep my notepad. WEST You know, Artemus, I think you underestimate the convenience of a pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: carrying some costumed swells pass through wrought-iron gates guarded by some of McGrath's ex-Rebs. FOLLOW it up a Spanish moss-draped drive to a huge Garden District mansion. As the carriage pulls to a stop in front... WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                            3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim West drops to the ground from where he'd hitched a ride underneath. He rolls into the shadows of the house. When he stands, he's face to face with a huge GUARD with a gun. GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got about as much chance of havin' an invitation as him. He smirks at a lawn jockey.    West reaches into his coat WEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact, got it right here. He withdraws his hand. While the Guard squints at his empty palm, West grabs his head with his other hand and smacks it into the lawn jockey's fist... clang! West leans the cold-cocked Guard against the house, uses his shoulder as a step, boosting him up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West grabs the ironwork underneath and acrobatically swings himself over the rail. As he BREAKS the PANE on the French door with his gun butt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West lets himself in. Then just as he's about to part the heavy drapes... he hears women's voices approaching. WOMAN (O.S.) (in a Spanish accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... get your hands off me! Now Miss Lippenreider, Amazonia and Munitia (bewigged and wearing costumes) wrangle a beautiful and defiant Latina into the room. When she turns we recognize she's the singer from Fat-Can's. Rita is in her early 20s, wearing a 19th-Century camisole so scanty, it makes it hard to concentrate on what she's saying. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me in the dungeon with all those smelly, dirty bearded men ... but I am not goin' in there. AMAZONIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You applied for the position. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a standing up position.   I'm an entertainer, not a... Amazonia grabs her by the throat, choking the word off. MISS LIPPENREIDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be selfish and stupid. He always spoils his new girl. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well gimme a simple diamond bracelet instead of that...

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH DOOR
dialogues.text: A ramp leads to a large bed. A leather and steel prosthesis is hanging from pulleys attached to the ceiling. MUNITIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not so bad... once the metal warms up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Amazonia just picks her up and drags the hapless Rita into the room. West emerges from behind the curtains, shakes his head. Weird. He eases out the door and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West hears the PARTY DIN coming from down below.     He goes to the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: OVER STAIR LANDING
dialogues.text: The scene below is hallucinogenically surreal. A Babel of foreign languages is the first thing that strikes us. Avant garde MUSIC is coming from two 10x10 quartet boxes on either side of the room to create stereo. SULTRY WOMAN (O.S.) An authentic cowboy outfit... complete with six-guns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West turns to see who busted him. Coming his way is a ravishing Chinese girl dressed up as a DRAGON LADY. DRAGON LADY What a terribly clever costume, Mr...? WEST ... West.   Jim West. DRAGON LADY Well... West meets East. Mae Lee East. (holds out delicate hand) Are you here alone, Mr. West? WEST Actually I'm, uh trying to surprise an old friend -- General McGrath. Seen him around anywhere? MISS EAST (DRAGON LADY) I don't believe that name was on our guest list. And I would know. I'm Dr. Loveless's personal assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name means something to West.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Dr. Arliss Loveless...? One of the great founders of the Confederacy with Jefferson Davis. Funny how most people think he's dead. MISS EAST Tonight's his coming-out party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW them as she takes his arm and leads him down the stairs, into the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West surveys the crowd. MISS EAST See anybody that looks familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West scans the room.    Stops. WEST Matter of fact, I do.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WITH BIG HAIR
dialogues.text: She's got the mole, too.    Gordon has apparently encored his Soiled Dove get-up. Miss East sees who he's looking at. She makes a pouty face as there's a flourish from the STEREO QUARTET. MISS EAST I'm... jealous. (blows a little kiss at him) Meet me later... in the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West watches as she joins...

dialogues.speaker: LOVELESS' WOMEN
dialogues.text: Miss East leads them in a sober rendition of "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" in front of a large doorway. DISTAFF CORPS (singing) 'Mine eyes have seen the glory Of the coming of the Lord...'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From behind the doors we hear the WHIR of an ELEVATOR. It stops with a CLUNK. Suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: bursts open and Abraham Lincoln in a mini-float appears. It's decked out like Lincoln's box at Ford's theater. On its own power, it moves past the laughing party-goers in the foyer. Now the women throw grapes on the floor. DISTAFF CORPS (singing) 'He has trampled down the vintage Where the grapes of wrath are stored!'

dialogues.speaker: ANGLE ON WHEELS OF WHEELCHAIR
dialogues.text: are what's trampling down the vintage. West takes in the whole man. Very curious. Then suddenly... KABOOM!

dialogues.speaker: ABE'S HEAD
dialogues.text: It explodes like a pinata. Up from the hole in his neck peeps... DR. ARLISS LOVELESS. LOVELESS (impishly) Don't you just hate that song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Southern crowd gasps at Loveless's dramatic appearanc LOVELESS Why, y'all look like you've seen a ghost! It's me, dear friends, alive and kicking! Well, alive, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he giggles, the distaff corps surround him and remove the Lincoln paraphernalia. Then step aside, revealing...

dialogues.speaker: DR. LOVELESS
dialogues.text: is half a man. Literally. Cut off at the waist and mounted on a wheelchair platform that is powered by an engine, he is a man bereft of tuchus, kishkes and everything else in that vicinity that makes life interesting.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LOVELESS (chuckles) We may've lost the war, but heaven knows... we haven't lost our sense of humor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Loveless looks down at himself, smoothes half of his Fritz Lang Metropolis-style suit. His face turns dark as he surveys the crowd. LOVELESS Not even when we've lost a lung... a spleen... a bladder... two legs... thirty-five feet of small intestine and our ability to reproduce... (like a preacher) All in the name of the South... (then quietly) ... do we lose our sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can hear a pin drop.    Loveless turns to the foreign dignitaries. LOVELESS I owe a deep debt of gratitude to my friends across the sea for their comfort and... succor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly seems distracted by the comely beauties that surround him. Then abruptly, manically... LOVELESS So...! Mi casa es su casa! Ma maison est a vous! Let the party begin!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless signals to the quartets to resume playing. Miss East leans down and whispers in his ear. Loveless looks in West's direction. Now Loveless wheels over to West. West isn't hiding. He's cocky in the face of rolling danger. LOVELESS Mr. West, how nice of you to join us tonight... and add color to these monochromatic proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West keeps a lid on his temper.    Two can play at this game.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Well, when a man comes back from the dead, it's an occasion to stand and be counted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless smiles slightly. LOVELESS Miss East informs me that you were expecting to meet General McGrath here. I knew him years ago... but haven't seen him in a coon's age. WEST I bet a man like yourself would find it difficult to keep in touch with even half the people you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger flickers in Loveless's eyes.    He looks to Miss East. LOVELESS Perhaps the lovely Miss East will keep you from being a slave to your disappointment. WEST Well, you know beautiful women... they encourage you one second, cut the legs out from under you the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless's face drops. He is no longer amused. Miss East winks at West, then accompanies Loveless in the direction of the study where...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General McGrath waits impatiently. He takes two champagnes off a passing tray, guzzles them, then wipes his mouth on Dolly Madison's bustle. As his eyes sweep the room...

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: He ducks behind a mountain man carrying the French tricolor. When Loveless and General McGrath disappear into the study and close the door, West eases after them. He pauses as he passes the "Soiled Dove," leans into her big bouffant. He regards a stained-glass window patterned with a spider over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Hey, honey... I see a big ole spider up on the wall. Hope it doesn't drop down your pretty dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Soiled Dove jumps a little, West continues over to the study door. Now the Soiled Dove turns, and we see the scared/confused expression. Maybe it's because she is not Artemus.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: He's the mountain man in the fringe jacket. And right now he's shaking his head as he watches West resort to a decidedly low-tech surveillance method of Loveless's study. GORDON Peeking through the keyhole...? So 18th Century.

dialogues.speaker: KEYHOLE
dialogues.text: McGrath paces in front of Loveless's desk. McGRATH Dr. Loveless, my men are ready to go to war with no weapons to fight. Ever since the nitro and the guns were destroyed at Fat- Can's, lice and demoralization have set in! LOVELESS Your men will have their weapons tonight. And my promise that they will be part of the greatest military victory of this century!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath's face relaxes into a pyorrheic grin. McGRATH Oh, you're a pip, sir! I'd follow you into the maw of Cerberus himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless takes pencil in hand and draws a map on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LOVELESS And so you shall. (makes an X) Have your men here at... 10 o'clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless wheels his chair toward the door with McGrath behind him folding up the map...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ducks out of the way as Loveless and McGrath emerge from the study. As they disappear into the throng of well- wishers, West takes a thin lock-pick out of his hat band. It takes him a moment or two, but the LOCK finally CLICKS. Then West slips inside, apparently undetected -- except by an unimpressed Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moves quickly to the desk past walls filled with oil portraits of various Loveless relatives. The one behind the desk is in the style of Gainsborough. A Loveless uncle is standing on a windswept grouse moor, two English setters by his side, a Holland and Holland double held in the crook of his arm. West turns his attention to the desk blotter. There's a faint imprint where Loveless drew the map. West takes his penknife and a pencil -- grates some graphite into the depressions. He's just about to do a rubbing on a piece of paper when... someone swipes it out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MISS EAST
dialogues.text: Hands on hips, she gives him a "naughty, naughty" look. MISS EAST I said to meet me in the foyer. WEST Oh, the foy-aay. Sorry, I've never been much good at French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But instead of scolding him further, Miss East plants an over-heated kiss on him. Tongues are involved. As they break, she gives a little nod of approval. MISS EAST Au contraire...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She pushes him down into Dr. Loveless's chair. MISS EAST So let's see, Mr. West... are you a dangerous spy of some sort? Or just a handsome cowboy who likes to... poke around. WEST Um... that second one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to undo the buttons of his trousers. But West has a job to do. Well, maybe he can do two jobs at once...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: is being the perfect party guest, moving through the crowd chit-chatting with this person and that (in French, Spanish, German) when he sees something of interest. Munitia and Lippenreider come out of an upstairs bedroom, lock it behind them. Hmmm. What's in there? As he starts upstairs, Amazonia appears, blocking his way. GORDON Howdy there... big sturdy gal. Yer dance card full?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazonia stares at him, then spiels off a couple lines in a foreign language that makes Gordon's eyes widen. He understands what she said and it's not flattering. Gordon moves off in a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are locked in a passionate embrace. West manages to position her nearly-naked rear end over the graphite powder. Very carefully, he stands, pushing her buttocks onto the desk and then rolling her off. The imprint on her left cheek is perfect. But unfortunately, it's backwards!

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: Damn. He lets Miss East concentrate on what she's doing, which from the SOUNDS O.S., doesn't appear to be a demonstration of the correct way to butter corn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: West spies a mirror on the other side of the room and raises her ass up into position so he can see the corrected reflection.

dialogues.speaker: MIRROR
dialogues.text: COMES INTO VIEW. It clearly shows the meeting place to be Malheureux Point, northeast of New Orleans. But the mirror reflects something else of interest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The painting behind him has come to life. The Loveless in the painting swings a real shotgun around and is pointing it at the back of West's head.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: suddenly contorts his upper torso just as an EXPLOSION rips the back of the chair where his head would have been. He draws and SHOOTS the would-be assassin, who falls out of the painting, dead. West turns to see...

dialogues.speaker: MISS EAST
dialogues.text: A surprised look on her face. A hole in her forehead. He lowers her head gently to the ground, regards her map-imprinted rear end. WEST Thanks for helpin' me get to the bottom of this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: emerges just as a Kentucky reel starts up. He weaves his way through the dance floor and spots the Soiled Dove look-alike out on the floor. West reluctantly straightens his shoulders and cuts in. This bold move gets some looks of disapproval from the pecan pie crowd.

dialogues.speaker: WEST AND SOILED DOVE RINGER
dialogues.text: dancing. Both look straight ahead, not at each other. West so as not to attract any more attention. His partner because she's scared shitless of this strange Negro who keeps hounding her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Real impressed the way you got the dance floor staked out. Maybe one of your missin' scientists'll cut in. (dip) Thought you should know that while you were trying to decide what shoes to wear tonight... (twirl) I found that our host, Dr. Loveless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West looks over to where Loveless is leading a contingent of foreigners out a side exit. WEST ... is meeting McGrath and his troops at Malheureux Point in an hour. (bends her back) So you enjoy the party. I'm gonna go save the Republic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soiled Dove look-alike is speechless.    Before he goes, West leans in, smirks. WEST But I will say, good work on your bladders tonight... they're damn perky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just to dig the grave deeper, West lays hands on them and gives them a little squeeze. This immediately elicits a scream and a slap in the face that shocks the bejesus out of the black cowboy. And he's not the only one.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: staring at him. We know what they're thinking, but the Mountain Man behind West says it for everyone. GORDON/MOUNTAIN MAN Hang him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Gordon opens his deerskin jacket to reveal his own rope, which he throws to the mob. West looks back at the character in amazement. That's Gordon?! Before West can say or do anything, guns are at his temple, and he's swept out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gordon calmly straightens his coonskin cap, seemingly uninterested in West's imminent hanging. In the hubbub of everyone rushing out for the hanging, Gordon heads up the unguarded stairs to the locked room. As he pulls out his high tech auto-wind lock-pick and quickly gains entrance to the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand-held torches illuminate. The rope is tossed over a lamp post. PAN DOWN TO where one of the mob, dressed as GEORGE WASHINGTON, is binding West's hands behind his back. GEORGE WASHINGTON Looks like we're gonna have to teach y'all a little lesson on how to behave in polite society. WEST Don't grab a white lady's boobies at the big redneck dance. Is that the lesson? Well, I learned it. Don't scratch your head with the shrimp fork. I got that one too. So whaddaya say we call this off?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: eases in, stops at what he sees. And it sure ain't scientists. Beside the bed, locked in an iron disco-like cage, is Rita, still wearing her scanty outfit. Gordon squints at her, gives a charming smile. GORDON I feel as if we know each other from someplace...? RITA Try again, buster...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a breath as if she's going to start screaming. Gordon quickly holds up a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 6/15/98

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON Ma'am, please! While I realize I look like something straight out of James Fenimore Cooper... I mean you no harm. My name is Artemus Gordon. And you look like you're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Rita's amazement, Gordon opens his jacket and unbuttons his vest to reveal... a complete miniature tool shop. Quickly he pulls out a thin cable and attaches it to a tiny wheel on the spur of one of his boots. RITA I'm Rita. I was hired here as an entertainer. Not that I'm complaining, but what are you doin' in here? GORDON (looking up miles of leg) Looking for some missing scientists... not that I'm complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon unsnaps the sole of his shoe. It becomes a pedal that operates the wheels' rotation. Now he removes a bit and handle from his vest and attaches the cable. Starts to pump his foot. It's a foot-powered drill. GORDON I'm a special U.S. Marshal on assignment from the President. RITA (almost impressed) If you're so special, how come you're lookin' up here when Loveless has 'em all workin' down in the dungeon? (rattles bars impatiently) Get me out of here and I'll take you down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99                            4

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON Too late. The 'dungeon' is cleaned out. It was the first place I checked, right after I sampled the gumbo. Bit heavy on the okra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Rita isn't listening to the food review. Her mind's racing. Finally, the LOCK CLICKS and the cage door swings open. Gordon takes the distressed damsel in his arms, lifts her out. RITA (suddenly a coquettish smile) Thank you... Artemus, was it? GORDON One doesn't forget a smile like that. Now where in the world was it...? Have you ever played the Empire Room... the Bijou Cafe perhaps...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West is lifted onto the back of a wagon. With the noose dangling in front of his nose, West addresses the crowd. WEST Can I have everyone's attention please. I think we've had a series of major misunderstandings and I'd like to take a moment to clear them up. First, the whole drumming on the boobies thing. In my native land, Africa, my ancestors used drums to communicate between villages. I'm sure y'all can see that this young girl here can communicate all the way down to Baton Rouge. Hell, on a clear day, we might even get Galveston. All I was saying was, 'How're you doing,' 'My name's Jim,' 'How's your mama?' (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 4/9/99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST (CONT'D) Second misunderstanding. That redneck comment. I'm getting the sense that some of you took that negatively. You know, some of my best friends are whiskey-guzzling, pot-bellied rednecks just like y'all here. (then) That slavery thing, I don't see what the big deal was. Hell, who wouldn't want somebody to run around for them doing chores. Are you going to get your big, fat, lazy ass out of bed every morning and pick your own damn cotton. I don't think so. (then) Let's head on inside and knock back some shine. Come on, back inside. No. Okay. (to Soiled Dove) I stand before you as a man who realizes he has done something wrong and I am prepared to do the right thing. Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soiled Dove gasps. WEST I'll take that as a no. Darling, would it help at all if I said I thought you were a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA FINDS the Soiled Dove.    She faints.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: WEST Guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As West searches desperately for signs of rescue by his "partner," suddenly the wagon lurches forward... GEORGE WASHINGTON Hang him!

dialogues.speaker: WEST'S FEET
dialogues.text: As they plummet toward the ground.

dialogues.speaker: WEST'S NECK
dialogues.text: The rope catches... and stretches!

dialogues.speaker: WEST'S FEET
dialogues.text: As they slowly touch the ground. Nobody is more confused than West.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: How the fuck did that happen? But before anybody can figure out Gordon's trick rope, speak of the devil... GORDON (O.S.) Hey-yaa!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd turns with alarm to see...

dialogues.speaker: TEAM OF CHARGING HORSES
dialogues.text: Nostrils flared and wild-eyed, are having their rumps snapped by Gordon's reins. Rita holds on for dear life as the mad Mountain Man drives the carriage at full speed right into the crowd -- scattering them.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: He sees his opportunity for rescue, puts a foot into the back of George Washington, grabs his gun, and somersaults into the air...

dialogues.speaker: GORDON AND CARRIAGE
dialogues.text: lands squarely in the back. And just as the rope starts to stretch around his neck again, Gordon whirls around with a Bowie knife and cuts it.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: West leans into Gordon's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 6/15/98

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WEST Hang 'm...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, there's a VOLLEY of SHOTS from some cracker sharpshooters. West responds with an amazing display of RAPID-FIRE marksmanship, picking off half a dozen of Loveless's shooters, even while the carriage bumps wildly on its getaway. BLAMBLAMBLAMBLAM!!! WEST (still pissed, to Gordon) Hang'm!?! GORDON (to Rita) Meet my trigger-happy partner, James West... who doesn't seem to realize that my carefully planned diversion gave me the opportunity to search for the missing scientists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now West notices the half-dressed bombshell in the carriage. WEST Scientist, huh. GORDON This is Rita. I found her locked in a cage in Loveless's bedroom. She's an entertainer. RITA Um, maybe I haven't been quite honest about that... My name is Rita Escobar. I came to find Guillermo Escobar, the scientist, my... father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon's eyes pop. GORDON Professor Escobar?! He was the one I almost rescued that night when... (lightbulb) That's where I know you from! Fat-Can Candy's... you sang before I did. RITA Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 6/15/98

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON That was me. Burgundy dress with the bustle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon starts singing the song... West rolls his eyes, cuts off the chit-chat. WEST Look, Rita, I'm sorry you had the wrong agent working on your case. When I find your father I promise I'll send him back safely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that... West suddenly leaps over Rita -- lands on the back of one of the horses. He grabs a handful of mane, leans over and unclips the harness. And with a kick in the ribs, West is off at a gallop -- leaving Gordon, one remaining horse and an awed Rita behind to chew his dust. RITA He's impulsive, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Loveless and his visiting foreign dignitaries are sipping champagne. One of them is holding a little DOG in his arms, BARKING at something in the dark. General McGrath stands at the railing, uncharacteristically pensive. Loveless rolls over, hands him a glass of champagne. LOVELESS Well, General, it's been a long journey from New Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath visibly winces at the sound of it. McGRATH Sir, there isn't a day that passes that I don't contemplate it. LOVELESS Yes, and so do I. So do I. (reflexively reaches for missing legs) If I'd only had the scientific understanding of gunpowder and primers that I have today...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McGRATH That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless looks at him, puzzled, then gets it. LOVELESS Oh, you mean the stomach-churning carnage that earned you your unfortunate nom de guerre...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loveless speaks for the benefit of the others. LOVELESS What was that nickname again? McGRATH (reluctantly) 'Bloodbath' McGrath... the Butcher of New Liberty.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reb battalion waits in a foggy meadow that slopes down to marsh. Beyond that is the Gulf of Mexico. We recognize one of the REBS from the cathouse. He opens his pocket watch. REB #1 They oughta be here by now. REB #2 Maybe we're in the wrong place. REB #1 (rechecks map) No, we're supposed to wait 'xactly on this here spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they hear a CLANKING and SCREECHING coming from the marsh. They ready their arms and get in defensive positions. What they can't see through the fog is...

dialogues.speaker: MARSH
dialogues.text: amphibiously sludges up through the mud and reeds, passing by the dumbstruck soldiers as it heads to the center of the field. The contraption has a large cannon and Gatling guns bristling from several ports. The Rebs cheer their new weapon. THE WILD WILD WEST - Rev. 7/1/98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
